newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS - Metals prices extend decline, demand poor.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Metals prices extend decline, demand poor.

text.p: Pressure built on world industrial metal markets on Thursday when the price of copper fell conclusively below $1,900 per tonne.
Speculators opted to sell the sector as end-user demand in the global economy continues to run at mediocre levels.
Copper is now at its weakest since mid-July and aluminium is at a two-year low. Other industrial metals such as zinc, lead, nickel and tin also look shaky.
"The problem is one of sentiment. When it is poor as it is now it spreads throughout the market and one metal can easily pull others lower with it," one trader said.
Analyst Martin Squires at London Metal Exchange (LME) broker Rudolf Wolff pinpointed copper on Thursday after prices breached $1,900 which was an important technical chart support level.
"It does not look very good at the moment. It could well go down to $1,825 and $1,800," he said.
The market fell to $1,862 a tonne at one stage.
Given the lack of confidence it may well return to two-year lows seen in June of $1,745 during a panic sell-off after the Sumitomo Corp scandal.
"There was positive news earlier this week of stocks declining but it has been discounted," Squires said.
Aluminium hit a low at $1,429 on Thursday with rising stocks a highly-visible signal of sluggish industrial demand.
"There is insufficient demand in the market at the moment to hold the bears at bay...
"Moreover, we have not seen the necessary rise in U.S demand following the Labour Day holiday nor in Europe," brokerage GNI Ltd said in a daily commentary.
Analysts said a pick-up in buying by industry had been expected after the end of the slow northern summer.
But Squires said "people are just operating on a hand-to- mouth basis...nobody wants to buy in case prices go lower still."
Metal fabricators, mills and other users continued to de-stock, operating off their own working inventories.
With the LME's two big markets under pressure, the rest of the metals complex is pressured, even though there are some positive fundamental factors.
Zinc is showing signs of falling under $1,000, trading at $1,005 on Thursday, while lead is gradually getting close to dropping under $800 after business down to $805.
Low metal prices so far this year hit mining firms hard.
On Thursday Anglo-Australian giant RTZ-CRA reported a 22 percent slide in net adjusted earnings to $552 million in the first half of 1996, blaming weak metal prices, above all copper.
But the company said that in its view the outlook for all base metals, with the probable exception of copper, was bullish over the remainder of 1996 and through 1997.
